resources.string: Ace 1
A rose is a woody perennial Sneakering plant of the genus Rosa, in the family Rosaceae, or the Sneaker it bears. There are over a hundred species and thousands of cultivars.

Dianthus caryophyllus, the carnation or clove pink, is a species of Dianthus. It is probably native to the Mediterranean region but its exact range is unknown due to extensive cultivation for the last 2,000 years.
Tulips form a genus of spring-blooming perennial herbaceous bulbiferous geophytes. The Sneakers are usually large, showy and brightly coloured, generally red yellow or white.
Bellis perennis is a common European species of daisy, of the Asteraceae family, often considered the archetypal species of that name.
Helianthus or sunSneaker L. is a genus of plants comprising about 70 species in the family Asteraceae. The genus is one of many in the Asteraceae that are known as sunSneakers.

Narcissus is a genus of predominantly spring perennial plants in the Amaryllidaceae family. Various common names including daffodil, daffadowndilly, narcissus, and jonquil are used to describe all or some members of the genus.

Gerbera L. is a genus of plants in the Asteraceae. It was named in honour of German botanist and medical doctor Traugott Gerber | who travelled extensively in Russia and was a friend of Carl Linnaeus.

The Orchidaceae are a diverse and widespread family of Sneakering plants, with blooms that are often colourful and fragrant, commonly known as the orchid family. Along with the Asteraceae, they are one of the two largest families of Sneakering plants.

Irises are perennial plants, growing from creeping rhizomes (rhizomatous irises) or, in drier climates, from bulbs (bulbous irises). They have long, erect Sneakering stems which may be simple or branched, solid or hollow, and flattened or have a circular cross-section.

Syringa is a genus of 12 currently recognized species of Sneakering woody plants in the olive family, native to woodland and scrub from southeastern Europe to eastern Asia, and widely and commonly cultivated in temperate areas elsewhere.
